metadata.case_name: Appellants (Electricity Consumers) v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Appellants supplied electricity by respondent State for many years under individual agreements between 1946-1952 prescribing terms including fixed rates (tariffs) for 10 years operation.
Agreements contained no provision authorizing Government to increase rates during operation; charges at graded regressive rates, overall unit rates not to exceed 66 annas.
Government had single power grid: Tungabhadra, Machkund Hydro Electric, Nellore Thermal systems integrated.
State issued notified orders on 28 January 1955 (Machkund/Nellore, Tungabhadra/Chittoor) enhancing rates per Schedules A/B, effective prospectively from February 1955 meter readings.
Orders issued due to uneconomic tariffs (15 years old), increased labour/material costs causing continuous losses; Accountant-General queried deficits.
Revision considered in Madras but deferred due to States Reorganisation; post-1956, Andhra Chief Engineer proposed revisions leading to orders.
Appellants filed writ petitions under Art.226 in AP High Court challenging orders; single Judge allowed writs, held orders unauthorised under S.3.
Respondent filed Letters Patent Appeals; Division Bench reversed single Judge, held S.3 authorised orders, dismissed writs.
Subsequent writs dismissed by single Judge following Division Bench; appeals to SC by certificate and special leave.

Legislative history: Defence of India Act 1939, Rules incl. R.81(2); post-war Essential Supplies Act 1946 (Central/Madras); Madras Act 29/1949; Andhra adopted via Act 1/1955 (assent 21 Jan 1955), Schedule reduced to charcoal/electrical energy.
State not sole supplier; other private licensees exist, some increased rates negligibly.

legal_issues.text: Construction of Section 3 of Madras Essential Articles (Control and Requisitioning) Temporary Powers Act, 1949: Does it empower State to issue notified orders enhancing electricity tariffs in its supply agreements with consumers?
Do the impugned notified orders contravene Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution?
Do the impugned notified orders contravene Article 14 of the Constitution?

petitioner_arguments.text: S.3 must be construed harmoniously with Act's scheme; applies to citizen-citizen transactions, not State's own supply of essential articles to itself/consumers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule of harmonious construction; State not bound by own statute unless express/necessary implication (Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corp; Director of Rationing v. Corp of Calcutta)

petitioner_arguments.text: Power to 'regulate' under S.3(1) does not include increasing tariffs, only reducing; odd for State to regulate own supply rates.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.3(1) words; S.3(2) clauses mostly inapplicable to State

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders unreasonable, alter contract terms, violate Art.19(1)(f)/(g) right to receive supply at agreed rates.
Divergent rates (State consumers stationary vs. some licensees increased negligibly) discriminate under Art.14.

respondent_arguments.text: S.3(1) wide enough to regulate State's supply of electrical energy (essential article) for equitable distribution at fair prices, including modifying contract terms.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.3(1); illustrative nature of S.3(2) (King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee; Santosh Kumar Jain v. State)

respondent_arguments.text: 'Regulate' includes increasing rates for fair price given economic factors/losses.

court_reasoning.text: S.3(1) clear/wide: empowers regulating supply/distribution/transport of essential articles (incl. electrical energy) at fair prices; applies to State supply as emphasis on equitable distribution/fair prices, not producer identity; can modify contracts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words unambiguous; cannot limit artificially for harmony if not reasonably capable.

court_reasoning.text: S.3(2) illustrative, does not narrow S.3(1); S.3(2)(b) on prices applies to State sales/purchases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regulate includes increase/decrease for fair price based on economic factors.

court_reasoning.text: Orders reasonable under Art.19 as prospective, prevent supply cessation/losses to public treasury, ensure continued supply for community good; no claim rates excessive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Viewed from community perspective, assures supply at fair price.

court_reasoning.text: No specific material/evidence for Art.14 discrimination; vague allegations insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State not monopolist, but no comparative rates proven.

holdings.text: S.3(1) empowers State to issue notified orders regulating its electricity supply tariffs, including increases for fair prices.
Impugned orders reasonable restrictions in interests of general public, not violating Art.19(1)(f)/(g).
No violation of Art.14 due to lack of material.

precedents_cited.case_name: Director of Rationing and Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: State not bound by own statute unless express/necessary implication.

precedents_cited.case_name: Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule that State not bound by statute unless express/implied; applies to claiming benefits.
S.3(2) clauses illustrative of S.3(1) generality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Santosh Kumar Jain v. The State
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirms illustrative nature of specific clauses.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Essential Articles (Control and Requisitioning) Temporary Powers Act, 1949 (No. 29 of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers notified orders regulating supply/distribution/prices of essential articles (incl. electrical energy); applies to State supply.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14/19 challenged; orders as law, reasonable; writ jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Act No. 1 of 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Adopted Madras Act 29/1949; continued till after 1955.

outcome.summary: All 37 appeals dismissed; impugned notified orders upheld as valid under S.3, not violating Arts.14/19; writ petitions dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "The State is not bound by a statute unless it is so provided in express terms or by necessary implication."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies rule to S.3 construction re State's own supply.

key_quotes.text: "The word 'regulate' is wide enough to confer power... either by increasing the rate, or decreasing the rate... for ensuring... fair price."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If electrical energy is one of the essential articles... there can be no difficulty in holding that a notified order can be issued under s.3(1) for regulating the supply... at a fair price."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms S.3 applies to electricity supply by State.
